newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks rally to year high in early trade.
newsitem.headline: French stocks rally to year high in early trade.

text.p: French stocks surged on Friday to their highest levels of the year on big gains in European bond prices, a strong dollar and signs that striking truckers could be about to call an end to a damaging 12-day strike.
"It's an ideal scenario," a trader said.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index was up 17.30 points, or 0.76 percent, at 2,307.61 at 1000 GMT after sailing through the psychological 2,300 barrier in the first few minutes of trading.
Traders say the path is clear up until a resistance level at 2,320. "If we break past 2,320, we're on the way to 2,400-2,450," another trader predicted.
The index's all-time high, set in February 1994, is 2,360.98 points.

The bourse is only now catching up with other European markets that have risen from one record to another this year. Analysts say equities investors have taken heart from a recent public debate about the franc-mark exchange rate and hope it will lead to both a weaker franc and lower interest rates.
Investors also heaved a great sigh of relief on Friday after truck drivers' unions said they were eager to negotiate an end to the strike that was threatening thousands of businesses.
"A lot of investors are buying on the expectation of a year-end rally fuelled by window-dressing," the trader said.
Activity centred on shares that have underperformed the market this year. Publishing group Havas, one of the biggest laggards, climbed for the second day in a row.
After rallying on Thursday on reports that shareholder Alcatel Alsthom was pushing it to boost shareholder value, Havas rose a further 3.19 percent to 378 francs on Friday.
The CAC-40 November futures contract was 18 points higher at 2,310.
Early volume was a heavy 760 million francs, swollen by activity linked to the expiry of monthly futures and options contracts.
